resources.string: Astronaut Chris Hadfield became the first person to record a music video in open space — aboard the ISS, he performed a cover of David Bowie’s “Space Oddity”. Even more surprisingly, he later released a full album, *“Space Sessions: Songs from a Tin Can”*, partially recorded in zero gravity.

In 2007, Radiohead released the album “In Rainbows” on a “pay what you want” basis — including $0. Many downloaded it for free, but the average payment was $6. This revolutionized the industry and marked the beginning of the era of digital trust between artists and fans.

In 1985, Soviet authorities banned the song “We Are the World” (USA for Africa), claiming lyrics “over-idealize humanity” and allegedly “undermine class vigilance”. Meanwhile, in the USSR, copies were secretly distributed on X-ray film — known as “bone records”.

Studies show that rhythmic music helps Parkinson’s patients regain gait and coordination. The brain synchronizes with the rhythm — effectively “rebooting” motor functions. In some clinics, music therapy is even used as part of treatment.
